grade.subject:
Saftey goggles This is the most important piece of saftey equipment You must always where eye protection when working with dangerous chemicals This peice of protective equipment is essential
Bunsen burner The Bunsen burner is a metal tube that produces a flame from gas such as methane, propane, or butane. It is used in the lab for heating and sterilizing. The Bunsen burner is named after German chemist Robert Bunsen. This peice of equipment is used for heating and sterilizing
Test tube A test tube is a glass or plastic tube used for holding, mixing, and heating small quantities of liquid chemicals. Test tubes often have a flared top to help with pouring. They come in a variety of sizes. This is used for holding, mixing and heating small quantities of chemicals
Crucible Crucibles are containers used for heating substances to very high temperatures. They are generally made from materials such as porcelain, nickel, and alumina. This is used for heating substances to very high temperatures
Florence flask Florence flasks are often used as a container to hold liquids. It has a round body, a long neck, and often a flat bottom. It is designed for uniform heating, boiling, distillation and ease of swirling; it is produced in a number of different glass thicknesses to stand different types of use. This is often used for uniform heating , boiling and distillation
Erlenmeyer flask This is a type of chemistry flask with a conical shaped body, a cylindrically shaped neck, and a flat bottom It generally has measurement marks on the side. The cone shape reduces losses from evaporation and helps to prevent spills when stirring the liquid. It has a cone shape that helps reduce losses from evaporation
Graduated cylinder A tall skinny cylinder used to measure volumes. It is generally a more accurate way to measure volume than a typical beaker or flask. This is used to accuratly measure volume
Corks Corks are used to block the opening on test tubes. This is done to reduce losses from evaporation, or prevent spills This is used to block the opening on test tubes
Funnel A funnel is a pipe with a wide mouth that helps to pour substances into a container without spilling. In a chemistry lab, funnels are often used together with filters to separate a mixture. This is used when pouring substances from one container into another
Pipet A narrow glass tube used to transfer liquids from one place to another Pipettes sometimes are used for measurement. The accuracy of different pipettes varies widely. This is used to transfer liquids from one place to another
Beaker A beaker is a glass container with a flat bottom and a small spout for pouring. It is used in the chemistry lab for mixing, heating, and stirring liquids. Beakers come in various sizes and are shaped like a cylinder. It has a flat bottom and a small spout for pouring
//not done, skip? Chemical reactionsIn this module you will learn about some common chemical reactions, what they are, and how they workCreating waterPhotosynthesisDecomposing waterDecomposing lithium carbonateBurning methaneZinc in acidNeutralizing an acidNewtons laws and gravityIn this module you will learn about Newtons laws, and gravity. By the end of this module you will understand the basics of Newtons laws, and how they apply to the real world example of launching a rocket!First, choose the material and the fuel you would like to use in your rocket. Then click the launch button to launch your rocket! The higher your rocket goes, the more you will learn.To turn off the popups, simple deselect Active Learning the settings menuSteelSteel is a mixture of several metals (this is called an alloy) but most of it is iron.Something made of pure iron is softer than steel because the atoms can slip over one another. If other atoms like carbon are added, they are different from iron atoms and stop the iron atoms from sliding apart so easily. This makes the metal stronger and harder.Althought steel is stronger and lighter than iron, it is often not strong or light enough for use in most rocketsAluminiumAluminum is a chemical element. It is the most abundant metal, and is known for its resistance to corrosion and its light weight. Aluminum, however, melts at the high reentry temperatures. So, if a rocket needs to come back to Earth (like the Space Shuttle), heat shield tiles are addedTitaniumTitanium is a very strong metal. It is chemical element number 22 on the periodic table Titanium is used for making the strongest and lightest parts of fighter jets, aircraft, and rocketsHowever, it can burn at high temperatures, and titanium dust is extremely flammable. Carbon composite It has the highest compressive strength of all the reinforcing materials (composites), and it has a high strength to weight ratio and low coefficient of thermal expansion The density of carbon fiber is also much lower than the density of steel.Carbon fiber is in the form of several thousand long, thin strands of material that is composed of mostly carbon atoms.SpringSpring propelled rockets use the potential energy stored in a compressed spring, to form kinetic energy, and launch the rocket upThese types of rockets are easy to make at home, however, they do not go very high!Compressed airCompressed air rockets use the pressure of a compressed air tank, to form kinetic energy launching the rocket upThese systems are more powerful then spring powered ones, however, they Solid fuelSolid rocket fuels are those in which the fuel and oxidiser compounds are already combined.Most use an aluminium powder as the fuel and an ammonium perchlorate as the oxidiser, while an iron powder is used as a catalyst for the reaction.Solid fuels are generally used more for the initial launch sequence, when the speed needs to be at its maximum, whereas liquid fuels are used later so the speed can be adjusted to get the rocket’s payload on to the right trajectory.Liquid fuelLiquid propellants separate fuel and oxidisers and the two are combined in a combustion chamber where they burn and are ﬁred out from the base of the rocket.iquid fuels are further subcategorised into either petroleum, cryogens or hypergols.Petroleum is fuel derived from crude oil and hydrocarbons, it consists of a highly refined kerosene mixed with liquid oxygen.Cryogens are those stored at very low temperatures (such as liquid hydrogen)Hypergols are able to self-ignite on contact between the fuel and the oxidiser. These fuels simply needs nitric acid in order to ignite and are frequently used for propulsion when out in space.GravityGravity is one of the four fundamental forces of nature, althought it is the weakest of these four forces, it is important to life on Earth and the structure of the universe.Everything that has matter generates gravity, from a grain of sand to the largest objects in the universe. The larger an object is, the stronger its forceIn order for a rocket to reach space, the force it exerts up, must be more than the force of gravity pulling it downNewtons Third LawRocket fuel works on the basis of Newton’s Third Law of Motion, which states that ‘every action is accompanied by an equal and opposite reaction'.By ﬁring fuel out the back of a rocket, the force propels it upwards with acceleration equal to the force at which the fuel is expelled.This law states that every action has an equal and opposite reactionRockets are based on this law, it is what causes the rocket to be pushed up, when the exahust is pushed downNewtons Second LawNewtons Second Law says that the acceleration of an object produced by a net (total) applied force is directly related to the magnitude of the force, the same direction as the force, and inversely related to the mass of the objectThis law states that aceleration is directly related to the force, and inversly related to the mass of an objectIt is because of this law that it is harder to push heavier things SpaceSpace begins about 100 km (62 miles) above Earth's surface.However, the space around Earth is not empty. There are many artificial satellites, about 5000, these are used for gather information, navigation, and communication amoung other things.There is also a large amount of space junk. Space junk is any human-made object orbiting Earth that no longer serves a useful purpose. Scientists estimate there are about 500,000 pieces of space junk today.Newtons First LawNewtons First Law says that an object at rest tends to stay at rest, and an object in motion tends to stay in motion, with the same direction and speedFor example, if you watch videos of astronauts in space, you will notice that their tools float, and they wont move unless the astronaut pushes or pulls it, at which point it will keep moving until it is stoppedThis law states that an object will stay at rest, or continue in motion unless acted on by an external forceIt is because of this law that objects stay in one spot in spaceSlowerIf a rocket was launched from jupiter, (where the gravity is higher) would it be faster, slower orthe same speed?FasterIf the same rocket was launched from the moon (where gravity is lower) would it be faster, slower, or the same speed?If a lighter material was used for the rocket body would it be faster, slower, or the same speed?If a you push a small object with some force, and then push a larger object with the same force, will the larger object go faster, slower or the same speed?Same speedIf a rocket runs out of fuel in space, but it is moving foward, in 1000 years, will it be travelling faster, slower or at the same speed? //this one should not be rocket WelcomeCreate your own Gold Ruberg machine to learn about the different types of energies, and how they can be transfered from one form to anotherYou can add objects from the menu on the left, when you are ready, click play!You can also choose from the prebuilt models, to get some ideas for your own machinesWant to put your machine to the test? Click the submit button to enter it into the weekly Gold Ruberg competition, and compete for prizes!Thermal energyMatter is made up of particles or molecules. These molecules move (or vibrate) constantly.A rise in the temperature of matter makes the particles vibrate faster. Thermal energy is what we call energy that comes from the temperature of matter. The hotter the substance, the more its molecules vibrate, and therefore the higher its thermal energy.However, thermal energy and temprature are not the same thing. The temperature of an object is to do with how hot or cold it is and is measured in degrees Celsius (°C). Meanwhile thermal energy depends on the number of molecules, and the temprature, it is meassure in Jolues To understand the differnece, consider the following example: A swimming pool at 40°C is at a lower temperature than a cup of tea at 90°C. However, the swimming pool contains a lot more water. Therefore, the pool has more thermal energy than the cup of tea even though the tea is hotter than the water in the pool.Kinetic energyAll moving things have kinetic energy. It is energy possessed by an object due to its motion or movement. These include very large things, like planets, and very small ones, like atoms. The heavier a thing is, and the faster it moves, the more kinetic energy it has.Mechanical energyMechanical energy is often confused with Kinetic and Potential Energy.Before that, we need to understand the word ‘Work’.‘Work’ is done when a force acts on an object to cause it to move, change shape, displace, or do something physical.For work to be done, the object must move, if you push as hard as you can on a wall, althought you exert a force, you do no work. However, if you move a pencil, althought the force used is smaller, you still do more work, because the pencil movedMechanical energy is the sum of kinetic and potential energy in an object that is used to do work. In other words, it is energy in an object due to its motion or position, or both.Gravitational energy Gravitational Potential energy is stored in the height of the object. Any time that a heavy object is kept high up, a force or power is likely to be holding it up there.Therefore, the higher the object, and the heavier it is, the more gravitational energy it hasElastic energyEach time energy is transferred into an object, two things happen. It is either used to do work, or it is stored in the object. If it is stored, the object is given potential energy that can be released to do work.Elastic energy is energy stored in stretched or compressed elastic materials.Elastic to kinetic energyElastic energy can be converted into kinetic energy. In this case the potential elastic energy stored in the spring is converted into kinetic energyIn this case, the total mechanical energy of the system remains the same, as no extra energy was created or destoryed, it only changed formsGravitational to kinetic energyGravitational potential energy can be converted into kinetic energy, or motion.As an object begins to fall, its gravitational energy decreases, but at the same time its kinetic energy increases. In this way, the total energy of the system remains the sameThermal to kinetic energyThermal energy can be transfered into kinetic energy. The thermal energy causes the molecules in the surrounding area to vibrate and move more, this in turn can push on other objects, causing kinetic energyAs the molecules push on some object, or on eachother, they begin to cool. In this way the thermal energy decreases, but the kinetic energy increases the same amountKinetic to elastic energyKinetic energy can be transffered into elastic potential energy. This can happen for exmaple when a ball falls on a spring, and compresses it. In this case, the kinetic energy of the ball is 0, as is the spring. However, the same amount of energy is still in the system, except it is now stored as potential energy in the springKinetic to gravitational energyKinetic energy can be transffered into gravitation energy. For example, when you throw a ball in the air as it rises it begins to slow, until eventually it stops and begins to fall againas the ball rises, its kinetic energy begins to become stored in gravitational potential energy. When the ball is at the top of its path, the kinetic energy is 0 (its not moving), this means that all the energy in the system is stored in gravitational potential energyKinetic to thermal energyKinetic energy can be transffered into thermal energy.WavesIn this module you will learn about basic wave terminology There are lots of waves all around us in everyday life. Sound is a type of wave that moves through matter and then vibrates our eardrums so we can hear. Light is a special kind of wave that is made up of photons. You can drop a rock into a pond and see waves form in the water. We even use waves (microwaves) to cook our food Waves can be divided into various categories depending on their characteristics. All waves can be categorized as either mechanical or electromagnetic.Mechanical wavesMechanical waves are waves that require a medium. This means that they have to have some sort of matter to travel through. These waves travel when molecules in the medium collide with each other passing on energy.One example of a mechanical wave is sound. Sound can travel through air, water, or solids, but it can't travel through a vacuum. It needs the medium to help it travel. Other examples include water waves, seismic waves, and waves traveling through a spring.This type of wave requries a mediumSound waves are an exmaple of this type of waveThis type of wave cannot travel throught a vacuumWater waves is this type of waveElectromagnetic wavesElectromagnetic waves are waves that can travel through a vacuum (empty space). They don't need a medium or matter.They travel through electrical and magnetic fields that are generated by charged particles. Examples of electromagnetic waves include light, microwaves, radio waves, and X-rays.This type of wave doesn't require a mediumMicrowaves are this type of waveRadio waves are this type of waveLight is this kind of waveTravelling wavesAnother way to describe a wave is by the direction that its disturbance is traveling. We can categorize waves into two categories, transverse and longitudinal wavesTransverse wavesTransverse waves are waves where the disturbance moves perpendicular to the direction of the wave.You can think of the wave moving left to right, while the disturbance moves up and down. One example of a transverse wave is a water wave where the water moves up and down as the wave passes through the ocean.This type of wave causes disturbances perpendicualr to the direction of the waveWater waves move in this type of wayLongitudinal wavesLongitudinal waves are waves where the disturbance moves in the same direction as the wave.One example of this is a wave moving through a stretched out slinky or spring. If you compress one portion of the slinky and let go, the wave will move left to right. At the same time, the disturbance (which is the coils of the springs moving), will also move left to right. Another classic example of a longitudinal wave is sound. As sound waves propagate through a medium, the molecules collide with each other in the same direction as the sound is moving.Sound waves move in this type of wayThis type of wave causes a disturbance in the same direction as the wave //6 AmplitudeThe amplitude of a wave is a measure of the displacement of the wave from its rest position, in other words it is how high/low the wave goesIn the case of water waves this can be thought of as the height of the wave, the higher the wave the larger the amplitudeThe amplitude is a measure of the strength or intensity of the wave. For example, when looking at a sound wave, the amplitude will measure the loudness of the sound. The energy of the wave also varies in direct proportion to the amplitude of the wave.This is the measure of the displacement of the waveThis can be thought of as the height of the waveThis is a measure of the strength or intensity of the waveThis represents the loudness for sound waves //7 WavelengthThe wavelength of a wave is the distance between two corresponding points on back-to-back cycles of a wave.This can be measured between two crests of a wave or two troughs of a wave. The wavelength is usually represented in physics by the Greek letter lambda (λ).In the term of water waves this can be thought of as how "long" the waves areThis measures the distance between two corresponding points on back to back cycles of a wave //8 Frequency and PeriodThe frequency of a wave is the number of times per second that the wave cycles. Frequency is measured in Hertz or cycles per second. The frequency is often represented by the lower case "f."The period of the wave is the time between wave crests. The period is measured in time units such as seconds. The period is usually represented by the upper case "T."The period and frequency are closely related to each other. The period equals 1 over the frequency and the frequency is equal to one over the period. They are reciprocals of each other //9 Velocity of a WaveAnother important property of a wave is the speed of propagation. This is how fast the disturbance of the wave is moving. The speed of mechanical waves depends on the medium that the wave is traveling through. For example, sound will travel at a different speed in water than in air.velocity = frequency * wavelength or v = f * λ //difference between this and mixtures? ClassifcationIn this module you will learn about the history of taxonomy, and how we calssify all living thingsCarolus LinnaeusBack in the 18th century, a Swedish man named Carolus Linnaeus thought it was important to organize living things, and he developed a system to do just that. His system first only contained plants, however, he quickly expanded it to include all living organisms. We still use the essence of his system today. Scientists are constantly refining the system based on new knowledge. Putting animals in order like this is called taxonomy. The taxonomists — people who name animals — use a book called the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, or ICZN, to tell them the rules for classifying animals.Linnaeus’s system His system has seven levels: Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus, and SpeciesEvery animal on the planet, down to the most microscopic creature you can imagine, can be classified according to this system.An easy way to remember the order is to use the memonic: King Phillip, come out, for goodness’ sake!KingdomGenerally, scientists agree there are six kingdoms. The animal kingdom (called Kingdom Animalia) is just one of those. The others are Achaebacteria, Eubacteria, Protists, Fungi and Plants.Originally, Linnaeus only identified two kingdoms: plant and animal. Some scientists think that viruses should have their own kingdom, but currently they are not included under this system.PhylumWithin the animal kingdom, the animals are divided into more than 30 phyla (which is the plural of “phylum”). Some of the better known phyla are Phylum Chordata and Phylum Arthropoda. Phylum Chordata is the one humans and all animals with backbones are in.Phylum Arthropoda contains insects, spiders and other animals with segmented bodies, like shrimp. Arthropods have their skeletons on the outside of their bodies (think of the hard shell of a lobster) and other characteristics in common. ClassThe third level of classification is class. For example, Phylum Chordata has classes in it like birds, mammals (Mammalia) and reptiles.OrderThe next level, or rank, is order. Orders are smaller groups within the different classes.Different orders include Lepidoptera and Carnivora. Lepidoptera is the order of moths and butterflies. Carnivora is the order within Mammalia that has the most diversity in animal size.FamilyThe fifth rank of classification is family. GenusGenus the second-to-last rank, and a genus may have only one or two animals in it. If animals are in the same genus, they are really closely related. In fact, you may not be able to tell them apart just by looking at them! When we write the name of the genus, we capitalize it and italicize it.For example, the genus of dogs (and wolves, too!) is Canis.SpeciesIf animals can breed together successfully, they are a species. When an animal is called by its scientific name, then that means it is being identified by its genus and species. We use a lowercase letter and italics for the species. For example, the scientific name of dogs is Canis familiaris; however, the scientific name of wolves is Canis lupus.Scientific NamesIn this module you will learn about common scientific names Modern HumansHomo sapiensHomo sapiensAfrican elephantLoxodonta africanaLoxodonta africanaBlack ratRattus rattusRattus rattusCatFelis domesticusFelis domesticusDogCanis lupus familiarisCanis lupus familiarisHorseEquus caballusEquus caballusLionPanthera leoPanthera leoWolfCanis lupusCanis lupusAppleMalus pumilaMalus pumilaCarrotDaucas carotaDaucas carotaLemonCitrus limoniumCitrus limoniumLettuceLactuca sativaLactuca sativaPotatoSolanum tubersumSolanum tubersumWatermelonCitrullus vulgarisCitrullus vulgarisWheatTriticum aestivumTriticum aestivumHeartThe Heart's function is to pump blood throughout the bodyThe Heart is considered a muscleThe heart consists of four different chambers: the left atrium, the right atrium, the left ventricle and the right ventricle.This organ is made up of four different chambersBrainThe Brain allows us to think, store memories, analyze and make judgments while at the same time controlling other areas automatically, such as breathing.The human brain weighs 3 pounds and is made up of 60% fat. The brain consists of the cerebrum, the brainstem, and the cerebellum.The cerebrum: this is responsible for a number of things like speech, motion, it also controls movement and learning it’s the largest part of the brain.The cerebellum: its main function is for helping with muscle movements, posture and balance\ The brainstem: plays a really important function by connecting the cerebrum and cerebellum to your spinal cord. It automatically looks after many of our bodies function like body temperature, digestion, heart rate and even things like sneezing and coughing.This organ controls all of our bodys vital functionsLungsBlood runs through our body, goes to the lungs to pick up oxygen from the air we breathe in and then drops off carbon dioxide, which we breathe out.The average adult individual breathes almost 11,000 liters of air every single day.The lungs have special little hairs in tubes in your lungs that move up and out. This helps the special cells that produce mucus. Mucus in the lungs is also specialized as it catches bacteria, dirt and dust that you breathe in as well as bacteria in the air.This organ supplies blood with oxygen, and removes carbon dioxideLiverThe liver is involved in almost every vital function of the body, such as making and storing energy; producing proteins vital for body function; processing drugs, and playing a vital role in immune function. Your liver is the second largest organ (after the skin), it weights about 3 poundsIt's the only organ that can completly regenerate, it only needs 25% of the orignial tissue, and can regrow in less than two weeksIt is the second largest organ in the bodyKidneyKidneys are two bean shaped organs, that are responsible for creating urineKidneys make hormones. The two most important ones that it makes are erythropoetin and renin.The kidney's most important work is keeping homeostasis. Homeostasis means that the body keeps a stable environment inside itselfThis organ is important in keeping homeostasisSeedInside a seed is an embryo, which is a tiny plant, and the endosperm, which are small leaves which supply the embryo food. The outside of the seed has a seed coat, which protects the embryo from injury or drying out.All seeds need moisture, oxygen and the right temperature to germinate, or grow. Until they have these conditions, the seed remains dormant and does nothing.This is where all plants start their livesMale flower Pollen is the male cell - it's the yellow dust made on the stamen, or male reproductive part, of the flower. Female FlowerThe female part is called the pistil, which contains the ovaries that produce eggs, and it's located in the center of the flower.The pistil also contains the stigma, a sticky bulb that the pollen attaches itself to. //add this Carbon DioxideCarbon dioxide is a gas that is present in the air.Plants collect carbon dioxide through tiny holes called stomates.Carbon dioxide is then combined with water and oxygen in a process known as photosynthesisThis gas is needed to complete photosynthesisEnergy from the SunSunlight is absorbed by a green chemical in the leaves, called chlorophilThe energy from the sun is used to split the water molecules into hydrogen and oxygenThis source of energy is required for photosynthesisOxygenDuring the process of photosynthesis, stomates are used to expel a gas called oxygen.Oxygen is very important for animals like humans – we need it to breathe!This is biproduct of photosynthesis is expelled by the plantGlucoseGlucose is a type of sugar, that the plant uses as energy to grow, and reproduceGlucose is produced throught photosynthesis, the word equation would be: Carbon Dioxide + Water + Light Energy = Glucose + OxygenThis is what the plant produces throught photosynthesis, which it uses to grow and reproduce //not done Ecological interactionIn this module you will learn about the different interactions in a food web and food chainFood chainEvery living plant and animal must have energy to survive. Plants rely on the soil, water, and the sun for energy. Animals rely on plants as well as other animals for energy.In an ecosystem, plants and animals all rely on each other to live. Scientists sometimes describe this dependence using a food chain or a food web.A food chain describes how different organisms eat each other, starting out with a plant and ending with an animal. Food WebIn any ecosystem there are many food chains and, generally, most plants and animals are part of several chains. When you draw all the chains together you end up with a food web.This describes an ecosystem with many food chainsTrophic LevelsSometimes scientists describe each level in a food web with a trophic level. Here are the five trophic levels: Level 1: Plants (producers)Level 2: Animals that eat plants or herbivores (primary consumers)Level 3: Animals that eat herbivores (secondary consumers, carnivores)Level 4: Animals that eat carnivores (tertiary consumers, carnivores)Level 5: Animals at the top of the food chain are called apex predators. Nothing eats these animals.These levels describe each level in a food web //kelp and plankton Producers Plants are producers. This is because they produce energy for the ecosystem.They do this because they absorb energy from sunlight through photosynthesis. They also need water and nutrients from the soil, but plants are the only place where new energy is made.Primary Consumers //crab Animals are consumers. This is because they don't produce energy, they just use it up. Animals that eat plants are called primary consumers or herbivores.These animals eat plantsAnother name for these animals is herbivores // squid, krill Secondary ConsumersAnimals that eat other animals are called secondary consumers or carnivores.These animals eat herbivores.Another name for these consumers is carnivores //penguin, walrus, seal, seagull Tertiary Consumer If a carnivore eats another carnivore, it is called a tertiary consumer.These are animals that eat other carnivoresOmnivore //fish Some animals play both roles, eating both plants and animals. They are called omnivores.These animals eat both plants and animalsDecomposers //plankton Decomposers eat decaying matter (like dead plants and animals). They help put nutrients back into the soil for plants to eat. Examples of decomposers are worms, bacteria, and fungi.These animals eat decaying matterWorms, bacteria and fungi belong to this group //killer whale, whale Apex preditorApex predators are predators with no natural predators of their own. They are at the top of their food chain.These animals are at the top of their food chainThese animals have not preditors of their own //not done //not done Plate TectonicsIn this module you will learn about plate tectonics, their different types, and how they shape our worldDivergent boundariesIn some places, the plates are pulling apart. New crust is pushed up from below. These are called divergent boundaries and they create rifts or valleys.Large lakes sometimes form in rifts.These places create rifts or valleysConvergent boundariesIn other places the plates are pushing against each other, creating mountains Sometimes one crust is dragged beneath – or subducted – below another oneOcean plates are heavier than continental plates so these plates are always dragged beneath.These boundaries create mountainsTransform boundariesA transform boundary happens when plates slide past each other but neither collide nor rip apart.The San Andreas Fault in California is a transform boundary.At these boundaries, plates slide past each other //not done

Saftey goggles This is the most important piece of saftey equipment You must always where eye protection when working with dangerous chemicals This peice of protective equipment is essential
Bunsen burner The Bunsen burner is a metal tube that produces a flame from gas such as methane, propane, or butane. It is used in the lab for heating and sterilizing. The Bunsen burner is named after German chemist Robert Bunsen. This peice of equipment is used for heating and sterilizing
Test tube A test tube is a glass or plastic tube used for holding, mixing, and heating small quantities of liquid chemicals. Test tubes often have a flared top to help with pouring. They come in a variety of sizes. This is used for holding, mixing and heating small quantities of chemicals
Crucible Crucibles are containers used for heating substances to very high temperatures. They are generally made from materials such as porcelain, nickel, and alumina. This is used for heating substances to very high temperatures
Florence flask Florence flasks are often used as a container to hold liquids. It has a round body, a long neck, and often a flat bottom. It is designed for uniform heating, boiling, distillation and ease of swirling; it is produced in a number of different glass thicknesses to stand different types of use. This is often used for uniform heating , boiling and distillation
Erlenmeyer flask This is a type of chemistry flask with a conical shaped body, a cylindrically shaped neck, and a flat bottom It generally has measurement marks on the side. The cone shape reduces losses from evaporation and helps to prevent spills when stirring the liquid. It has a cone shape that helps reduce losses from evaporation
Graduated cylinder A tall skinny cylinder used to measure volumes. It is generally a more accurate way to measure volume than a typical beaker or flask. This is used to accuratly measure volume
Corks Corks are used to block the opening on test tubes. This is done to reduce losses from evaporation, or prevent spills This is used to block the opening on test tubes
Funnel A funnel is a pipe with a wide mouth that helps to pour substances into a container without spilling. In a chemistry lab, funnels are often used together with filters to separate a mixture. This is used when pouring substances from one container into another
Pipet A narrow glass tube used to transfer liquids from one place to another Pipettes sometimes are used for measurement. The accuracy of different pipettes varies widely. This is used to transfer liquids from one place to another
Beaker A beaker is a glass container with a flat bottom and a small spout for pouring. It is used in the chemistry lab for mixing, heating, and stirring liquids. Beakers come in various sizes and are shaped like a cylinder. It has a flat bottom and a small spout for pouring

Then click the launch button to launch your rocket! The higher your rocket goes, the more you will learn.To turn off the popups, simple deselect Active Learning the settings menuSteelSteel is a mixture of several metals (this is called an alloy) but most of it is iron.Something made of pure iron is softer than steel because the atoms can slip over one another. If other atoms like carbon are added, they are different from iron atoms and stop the iron atoms from sliding apart so easily. This makes the metal stronger and harder.Althought steel is stronger and lighter than iron, it is often not strong or light enough for use in most rocketsAluminiumAluminum is a chemical element. It is the most abundant metal, and is known for its resistance to corrosion and its light weight. Aluminum, however, melts at the high reentry temperatures. So, if a rocket needs to come back to Earth (like the Space Shuttle), heat shield tiles are addedTitaniumTitanium is a very strong metal. It is chemical element number 22 on the periodic table Titanium is used for making the strongest and lightest parts of fighter jets, aircraft, and rocketsHowever, it can burn at high temperatures, and titanium dust is extremely flammable. Carbon composite It has the highest compressive strength of all the reinforcing materials (composites), and it has a high strength to weight ratio and low coefficient of thermal expansion The density of carbon fiber is also much lower than the density of steel.Carbon fiber is in the form of several thousand long, thin strands of material that is composed of mostly carbon atoms.SpringSpring propelled rockets use the potential energy stored in a compressed spring, to form kinetic energy, and launch the rocket upThese types of rockets are easy to make at home, however, they do not go very high!Compressed airCompressed air rockets use the pressure of a compressed air tank, to form kinetic energy launching the rocket upThese systems are more powerful then spring powered ones, however, they Solid fuelSolid rocket fuels are those in which the fuel and oxidiser compounds are already combined.Most use an aluminium powder as the fuel and an ammonium perchlorate as the oxidiser, while an iron powder is used as a catalyst for the reaction.Solid fuels are generally used more for the initial launch sequence, when the speed needs to be at its maximum, whereas liquid fuels are used later so the speed can be adjusted to get the rocket’s payload on to the right trajectory.Liquid fuelLiquid propellants separate fuel and oxidisers and the two are combined in a combustion chamber where they burn and are ﬁred out from the base of the rocket.iquid fuels are further subcategorised into either petroleum, cryogens or hypergols.Petroleum is fuel derived from crude oil and hydrocarbons, it consists of a highly refined kerosene mixed with liquid oxygen.Cryogens are those stored at very low temperatures (such as liquid hydrogen)Hypergols are able to self-ignite on contact between the fuel and the oxidiser. These fuels simply needs nitric acid in order to ignite and are frequently used for propulsion when out in space.GravityGravity is one of the four fundamental forces of nature, althought it is the weakest of these four forces, it is important to life on Earth and the structure of the universe.Everything that has matter generates gravity, from a grain of sand to the largest objects in the universe. The larger an object is, the stronger its forceIn order for a rocket to reach space, the force it exerts up, must be more than the force of gravity pulling it downNewtons Third LawRocket fuel works on the basis of Newton’s Third Law of Motion, which states that ‘every action is accompanied by an equal and opposite reaction'.By ﬁring fuel out the back of a rocket, the force propels it upwards with acceleration equal to the force at which the fuel is expelled.This law states that every action has an equal and opposite reactionRockets are based on this law, it is what causes the rocket to be pushed up, when the exahust is pushed downNewtons Second LawNewtons Second Law says that the acceleration of an object produced by a net (total) applied force is directly related to the magnitude of the force, the same direction as the force, and inversely related to the mass of the objectThis law states that aceleration is directly related to the force, and inversly related to the mass of an objectIt is because of this law that it is harder to push heavier things SpaceSpace begins about 100 km (62 miles) above Earth's surface.However, the space around Earth is not empty. There are many artificial satellites, about 5000, these are used for gather information, navigation, and communication amoung other things.There is also a large amount of space junk. Space junk is any human-made object orbiting Earth that no longer serves a useful purpose. Scientists estimate there are about 500,000 pieces of space junk today.Newtons First LawNewtons First Law says that an object at rest tends to stay at rest, and an object in motion tends to stay in motion, with the same direction and speedFor example, if you watch videos of astronauts in space, you will notice that their tools float, and they wont move unless the astronaut pushes or pulls it, at which point it will keep moving until it is stoppedThis law states that an object will stay at rest, or continue in motion unless acted on by an external forceIt is because of this law that objects stay in one spot in spaceSlowerIf a rocket was launched from jupiter, (where the gravity is higher) would it be faster, slower orthe same speed?FasterIf the same rocket was launched from the moon (where gravity is lower) would it be faster, slower, or the same speed?If a lighter material was used for the rocket body would it be faster, slower, or the same speed?If a you push a small object with some force, and then push a larger object with the same force, will the larger object go faster, slower or the same speed?Same speedIf a rocket runs out of fuel in space, but it is moving foward, in 1000 years, will it be travelling faster, slower or at the same speed?WelcomeCreate your own Gold Ruberg machine to learn about the different types of energies, and how they can be transfered from one form to anotherYou can add objects from the menu on the left, when you are ready, click play!You can also choose from the prebuilt models, to get some ideas for your own machinesWant to put your machine to the test? Click the submit button to enter it into the weekly Gold Ruberg competition, and compete for prizes!Thermal energyMatter is made up of particles or molecules. These molecules move (or vibrate) constantly.A rise in the temperature of matter makes the particles vibrate faster. Thermal energy is what we call energy that comes from the temperature of matter. The hotter the substance, the more its molecules vibrate, and therefore the higher its thermal energy.However, thermal energy and temprature are not the same thing. The temperature of an object is to do with how hot or cold it is and is measured in degrees Celsius (°C). Meanwhile thermal energy depends on the number of molecules, and the temprature, it is meassure in Jolues To understand the differnece, consider the following example: A swimming pool at 40°C is at a lower temperature than a cup of tea at 90°C. However, the swimming pool contains a lot more water. Therefore, the pool has more thermal energy than the cup of tea even though the tea is hotter than the water in the pool.Kinetic energyAll moving things have kinetic energy. It is energy possessed by an object due to its motion or movement. These include very large things, like planets, and very small ones, like atoms. The heavier a thing is, and the faster it moves, the more kinetic energy it has.Mechanical energyMechanical energy is often confused with Kinetic and Potential Energy.Before that, we need to understand the word ‘Work’.‘Work’ is done when a force acts on an object to cause it to move, change shape, displace, or do something physical.For work to be done, the object must move, if you push as hard as you can on a wall, althought you exert a force, you do no work. However, if you move a pencil, althought the force used is smaller, you still do more work, because the pencil movedMechanical energy is the sum of kinetic and potential energy in an object that is used to do work. In other words, it is energy in an object due to its motion or position, or both.Gravitational energy Gravitational Potential energy is stored in the height of the object. Any time that a heavy object is kept high up, a force or power is likely to be holding it up there.Therefore, the higher the object, and the heavier it is, the more gravitational energy it hasElastic energyEach time energy is transferred into an object, two things happen. It is either used to do work, or it is stored in the object. If it is stored, the object is given potential energy that can be released to do work.Elastic energy is energy stored in stretched or compressed elastic materials.Elastic to kinetic energyElastic energy can be converted into kinetic energy. In this case the potential elastic energy stored in the spring is converted into kinetic energyIn this case, the total mechanical energy of the system remains the same, as no extra energy was created or destoryed, it only changed formsGravitational to kinetic energyGravitational potential energy can be converted into kinetic energy, or motion.As an object begins to fall, its gravitational energy decreases, but at the same time its kinetic energy increases. In this way, the total energy of the system remains the sameThermal to kinetic energyThermal energy can be transfered into kinetic energy. The thermal energy causes the molecules in the surrounding area to vibrate and move more, this in turn can push on other objects, causing kinetic energyAs the molecules push on some object, or on eachother, they begin to cool. In this way the thermal energy decreases, but the kinetic energy increases the same amountKinetic to elastic energyKinetic energy can be transffered into elastic potential energy. This can happen for exmaple when a ball falls on a spring, and compresses it. In this case, the kinetic energy of the ball is 0, as is the spring. However, the same amount of energy is still in the system, except it is now stored as potential energy in the springKinetic to gravitational energyKinetic energy can be transffered into gravitation energy. For example, when you throw a ball in the air as it rises it begins to slow, until eventually it stops and begins to fall againas the ball rises, its kinetic energy begins to become stored in gravitational potential energy. When the ball is at the top of its path, the kinetic energy is 0 (its not moving), this means that all the energy in the system is stored in gravitational potential energyKinetic to thermal energyKinetic energy can be transffered into thermal energy.WavesIn this module you will learn about basic wave terminology There are lots of waves all around us in everyday life. Sound is a type of wave that moves through matter and then vibrates our eardrums so we can hear. Light is a special kind of wave that is made up of photons. You can drop a rock into a pond and see waves form in the water. We even use waves (microwaves) to cook our food Waves can be divided into various categories depending on their characteristics. All waves can be categorized as either mechanical or electromagnetic.Mechanical wavesMechanical waves are waves that require a medium. This means that they have to have some sort of matter to travel through. These waves travel when molecules in the medium collide with each other passing on energy.One example of a mechanical wave is sound. Sound can travel through air, water, or solids, but it can't travel through a vacuum. It needs the medium to help it travel. Other examples include water waves, seismic waves, and waves traveling through a spring.This type of wave requries a mediumSound waves are an exmaple of this type of waveThis type of wave cannot travel throught a vacuumWater waves is this type of waveElectromagnetic wavesElectromagnetic waves are waves that can travel through a vacuum (empty space). They don't need a medium or matter.They travel through electrical and magnetic fields that are generated by charged particles. Examples of electromagnetic waves include light, microwaves, radio waves, and X-rays.This type of wave doesn't require a mediumMicrowaves are this type of waveRadio waves are this type of waveLight is this kind of waveTravelling wavesAnother way to describe a wave is by the direction that its disturbance is traveling. We can categorize waves into two categories, transverse and longitudinal wavesTransverse wavesTransverse waves are waves where the disturbance moves perpendicular to the direction of the wave.You can think of the wave moving left to right, while the disturbance moves up and down. One example of a transverse wave is a water wave where the water moves up and down as the wave passes through the ocean.This type of wave causes disturbances perpendicualr to the direction of the waveWater waves move in this type of wayLongitudinal wavesLongitudinal waves are waves where the disturbance moves in the same direction as the wave.One example of this is a wave moving through a stretched out slinky or spring. If you compress one portion of the slinky and let go, the wave will move left to right. At the same time, the disturbance (which is the coils of the springs moving), will also move left to right. Another classic example of a longitudinal wave is sound. As sound waves propagate through a medium, the molecules collide with each other in the same direction as the sound is moving.Sound waves move in this type of wayThis type of wave causes a disturbance in the same direction as the wave //6 AmplitudeThe amplitude of a wave is a measure of the displacement of the wave from its rest position, in other words it is how high/low the wave goesIn the case of water waves this can be thought of as the height of the wave, the higher the wave the larger the amplitudeThe amplitude is a measure of the strength or intensity of the wave. For example, when looking at a sound wave, the amplitude will measure the loudness of the sound. The energy of the wave also varies in direct proportion to the amplitude of the wave.This is the measure of the displacement of the waveThis can be thought of as the height of the waveThis is a measure of the strength or intensity of the waveThis represents the loudness for sound waves //7 WavelengthThe wavelength of a wave is the distance between two corresponding points on back-to-back cycles of a wave.This can be measured between two crests of a wave or two troughs of a wave. The wavelength is usually represented in physics by the Greek letter lambda (λ).In the term of water waves this can be thought of as how "long" the waves areThis measures the distance between two corresponding points on back to back cycles of a wave //8 Frequency and PeriodThe frequency of a wave is the number of times per second that the wave cycles. Frequency is measured in Hertz or cycles per second. The frequency is often represented by the lower case "f."The period of the wave is the time between wave crests. The period is measured in time units such as seconds. The period is usually represented by the upper case "T."The period and frequency are closely related to each other. The period equals 1 over the frequency and the frequency is equal to one over the period. They are reciprocals of each other //9 Velocity of a WaveAnother important property of a wave is the speed of propagation. This is how fast the disturbance of the wave is moving. The speed of mechanical waves depends on the medium that the wave is traveling through. For example, sound will travel at a different speed in water than in air.velocity = frequency * wavelength or v = f * λ //difference between this and mixtures? ClassifcationIn this module you will learn about the history of taxonomy, and how we calssify all living thingsCarolus LinnaeusBack in the 18th century, a Swedish man named Carolus Linnaeus thought it was important to organize living things, and he developed a system to do just that. His system first only contained plants, however, he quickly expanded it to include all living organisms. We still use the essence of his system today. Scientists are constantly refining the system based on new knowledge. Putting animals in order like this is called taxonomy. The taxonomists — people who name animals — use a book called the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, or ICZN, to tell them the rules for classifying animals.Linnaeus’s system His system has seven levels: Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus, and SpeciesEvery animal on the planet, down to the most microscopic creature you can imagine, can be classified according to this system.An easy way to remember the order is to use the memonic: King Phillip, come out, for goodness’ sake!KingdomGenerally, scientists agree there are six kingdoms. The animal kingdom (called Kingdom Animalia) is just one of those. The others are Achaebacteria, Eubacteria, Protists, Fungi and Plants.Originally, Linnaeus only identified two kingdoms: plant and animal. Some scientists think that viruses should have their own kingdom, but currently they are not included under this system.PhylumWithin the animal kingdom, the animals are divided into more than 30 phyla (which is the plural of “phylum”). Some of the better known phyla are Phylum Chordata and Phylum Arthropoda. Phylum Chordata is the one humans and all animals with backbones are in.Phylum Arthropoda contains insects, spiders and other animals with segmented bodies, like shrimp. Arthropods have their skeletons on the outside of their bodies (think of the hard shell of a lobster) and other characteristics in common. ClassThe third level of classification is class. For example, Phylum Chordata has classes in it like birds, mammals (Mammalia) and reptiles.OrderThe next level, or rank, is order. Orders are smaller groups within the different classes.Different orders include Lepidoptera and Carnivora. Lepidoptera is the order of moths and butterflies. Carnivora is the order within Mammalia that has the most diversity in animal size.FamilyThe fifth rank of classification is family. GenusGenus the second-to-last rank, and a genus may have only one or two animals in it. If animals are in the same genus, they are really closely related. In fact, you may not be able to tell them apart just by looking at them! When we write the name of the genus, we capitalize it and italicize it.For example, the genus of dogs (and wolves, too!) is Canis.SpeciesIf animals can breed together successfully, they are a species. When an animal is called by its scientific name, then that means it is being identified by its genus and species. We use a lowercase letter and italics for the species. For example, the scientific name of dogs is Canis familiaris; however, the scientific name of wolves is Canis lupus.Scientific NamesIn this module you will learn about common scientific names Modern HumansHomo sapiensHomo sapiensAfrican elephantLoxodonta africanaLoxodonta africanaBlack ratRattus rattusRattus rattusCatFelis domesticusFelis domesticusDogCanis lupus familiarisCanis lupus familiarisHorseEquus caballusEquus caballusLionPanthera leoPanthera leoWolfCanis lupusCanis lupusAppleMalus pumilaMalus pumilaCarrotDaucas carotaDaucas carotaLemonCitrus limoniumCitrus limoniumLettuceLactuca sativaLactuca sativaPotatoSolanum tubersumSolanum tubersumWatermelonCitrullus vulgarisCitrullus vulgarisWheatTriticum aestivumTriticum aestivumHeartThe Heart's function is to pump blood throughout the bodyThe Heart is considered a muscleThe heart consists of four different chambers: the left atrium, the right atrium, the left ventricle and the right ventricle.This organ is made up of four different chambersBrainThe Brain allows us to think, store memories, analyze and make judgments while at the same time controlling other areas automatically, such as breathing.The human brain weighs 3 pounds and is made up of 60% fat. The brain consists of the cerebrum, the brainstem, and the cerebellum.The cerebrum: this is responsible for a number of things like speech, motion, it also controls movement and learning it’s the largest part of the brain.The cerebellum: its main function is for helping with muscle movements, posture and balance\ The brainstem: plays a really important function by connecting the cerebrum and cerebellum to your spinal cord. It automatically looks after many of our bodies function like body temperature, digestion, heart rate and even things like sneezing and coughing.This organ controls all of our bodys vital functionsLungsBlood runs through our body, goes to the lungs to pick up oxygen from the air we breathe in and then drops off carbon dioxide, which we breathe out.The average adult individual breathes almost 11,000 liters of air every single day.The lungs have special little hairs in tubes in your lungs that move up and out. This helps the special cells that produce mucus. Mucus in the lungs is also specialized as it catches bacteria, dirt and dust that you breathe in as well as bacteria in the air.This organ supplies blood with oxygen, and removes carbon dioxideLiverThe liver is involved in almost every vital function of the body, such as making and storing energy; producing proteins vital for body function; processing drugs, and playing a vital role in immune function. Your liver is the second largest organ (after the skin), it weights about 3 poundsIt's the only organ that can completly regenerate, it only needs 25% of the orignial tissue, and can regrow in less than two weeksIt is the second largest organ in the bodyKidneyKidneys are two bean shaped organs, that are responsible for creating urineKidneys make hormones. The two most important ones that it makes are erythropoetin and renin.The kidney's most important work is keeping homeostasis. Homeostasis means that the body keeps a stable environment inside itselfThis organ is important in keeping homeostasisSeedInside a seed is an embryo, which is a tiny plant, and the endosperm, which are small leaves which supply the embryo food. The outside of the seed has a seed coat, which protects the embryo from injury or drying out.All seeds need moisture, oxygen and the right temperature to germinate, or grow. Until they have these conditions, the seed remains dormant and does nothing.This is where all plants start their livesMale flower Pollen is the male cell - it's the yellow dust made on the stamen, or male reproductive part, of the flower. Female FlowerThe female part is called the pistil, which contains the ovaries that produce eggs, and it's located in the center of the flower.The pistil also contains the stigma, a sticky bulb that the pollen attaches itself to. //add this Carbon DioxideCarbon dioxide is a gas that is present in the air.Plants collect carbon dioxide through tiny holes called stomates.Carbon dioxide is then combined with water and oxygen in a process known as photosynthesisThis gas is needed to complete photosynthesisEnergy from the SunSunlight is absorbed by a green chemical in the leaves, called chlorophilThe energy from the sun is used to split the water molecules into hydrogen and oxygenThis source of energy is required for photosynthesisOxygenDuring the process of photosynthesis, stomates are used to expel a gas called oxygen.Oxygen is very important for animals like humans – we need it to breathe!This is biproduct of photosynthesis is expelled by the plantGlucoseGlucose is a type of sugar, that the plant uses as energy to grow, and reproduceGlucose is produced throught photosynthesis, the word equation would be: Carbon Dioxide + Water + Light Energy = Glucose + OxygenThis is what the plant produces throught photosynthesis, which it uses to grow and reproduce //not done Ecological interactionIn this module you will learn about the different interactions in a food web and food chainFood chainEvery living plant and animal must have energy to survive. Plants rely on the soil, water, and the sun for energy. Animals rely on plants as well as other animals for energy.In an ecosystem, plants and animals all rely on each other to live. Scientists sometimes describe this dependence using a food chain or a food web.A food chain describes how different organisms eat each other, starting out with a plant and ending with an animal. Food WebIn any ecosystem there are many food chains and, generally, most plants and animals are part of several chains. When you draw all the chains together you end up with a food web.This describes an ecosystem with many food chainsTrophic LevelsSometimes scientists describe each level in a food web with a trophic level. Here are the five trophic levels: Level 1: Plants (producers)Level 2: Animals that eat plants or herbivores (primary consumers)Level 3: Animals that eat herbivores (secondary consumers, carnivores)Level 4: Animals that eat carnivores (tertiary consumers, carnivores)Level 5: Animals at the top of the food chain are called apex predators. Nothing eats these animals.These levels describe each level in a food web //kelp and plankton Producers Plants are producers. This is because they produce energy for the ecosystem.They do this because they absorb energy from sunlight through photosynthesis. They also need water and nutrients from the soil, but plants are the only place where new energy is made.Primary Consumers //crab Animals are consumers. This is because they don't produce energy, they just use it up. Animals that eat plants are called primary consumers or herbivores.These animals eat plantsAnother name for these animals is herbivores // squid, krill Secondary ConsumersAnimals that eat other animals are called secondary consumers or carnivores.These animals eat herbivores.Another name for these consumers is carnivores //penguin, walrus, seal, seagull Tertiary Consumer If a carnivore eats another carnivore, it is called a tertiary consumer.These are animals that eat other carnivoresOmnivore //fish Some animals play both roles, eating both plants and animals. They are called omnivores.These animals eat both plants and animalsDecomposers //plankton Decomposers eat decaying matter (like dead plants and animals). They help put nutrients back into the soil for plants to eat. Examples of decomposers are worms, bacteria, and fungi.These animals eat decaying matterWorms, bacteria and fungi belong to this group //killer whale, whale Apex preditorApex predators are predators with no natural predators of their own. They are at the top of their food chain.These animals are at the top of their food chainThese animals have not preditors of their own //not done //not done Plate TectonicsIn this module you will learn about plate tectonics, their different types, and how they shape our worldDivergent boundariesIn some places, the plates are pulling apart. New crust is pushed up from below. These are called divergent boundaries and they create rifts or valleys.Large lakes sometimes form in rifts.These places create rifts or valleysConvergent boundariesIn other places the plates are pushing against each other, creating mountains Sometimes one crust is dragged beneath – or subducted – below another oneOcean plates are heavier than continental plates so these plates are always dragged beneath.These boundaries create mountainsTransform boundariesA transform boundary happens when plates slide past each other but neither collide nor rip apart.The San Andreas Fault in California is a transform boundary.At these boundaries, plates slide past each other //not done

//ok, so for this one, put it in models, just get the cell model, and have the images of the protiens and all that as particle systems that they can click on BiochemistryIn this module you will learn about the basics of carbohydrates, lipids, protiens, and nucleic acid, as well as celular respirationCarbohydrateCarbohydrates are chemical compounds that contain only oxygen, hydrogen and carbon. They are made up of joined-up sugars. Sugars have the general formula Cm(H2O)n, and are also known as saccharides.Certain carbohydrates are an important storage and transport form of energy in most organisms, including plants and animals.Carbohydrates are very good for energy, but, if a person eats more than needed, the extra is changed into fat.These molecules are very good for energy, however if too much of them are eaten, they are changed into fatThese molecules are made of joined-up sugarsLipidsA lipid is a type of organic molecule found in living things. It is oily or waxy. Fats are made from lipid molecules.Sources of lipid can be found in algae, seeds, meat, cheese, butter and fish. Lipids are long chains of carbon and hydrogen molecules. Lipids are classified as simple and complex. Examples of complex molecules could be steroids or phospholipids.A very important biological function of lipids is as lipid bilayers, the basis of many cell membranes. Another function of lipids is to serve as an energy reserve.In summary, lipids are a group of naturally occurring molecules that include fats, waxes, sterols, fat-soluble vitamins (such as vitamins A, D, E, and K), glycerides, phospholipids, and others. The main biological functions of lipids include storing energy, signalling, and acting as components of cell membranes.These molecules naturally occure in fats, waxes and fat-soluble vitaminsThese molecules are classified as either simple or complexThe main functions of this molelcule include signalling, storing energy, and building the cell membraneProtiensProteins are long-chain molecules built from small units known as amino acids. They are joined together with peptide bonds.Proteins are essential to all cells. proteins take part in virtually every process in cellsProteins do different things depending on their shape. They can be found in meat or muscle. They are used for growth and repair, making tissue cells and used for strengthening the bones.There are four things that determine what a protein will do. The first is the order of the amino acids. he second is the little twists in the chain. The third is how the entire thing is folded up. The fourth is whether it is made up of different sub-unitsThese molecules are made up of small units known as amino acidsThese molecules are found in large numbers in meat and muscleThese molecules are used for growth, repair, making tissue cells and strengthening bones amoung othersNucleic AcidsNucleic acids are large molecules where genetic information is stored. There are two types of nucleic acids: deoxyribonucleic acid, better known as DNA and ribonucleic acid, better known as RNA.Nucleic acids allow organisms to transfer genetic information from one generation to the next. When a cell divides, its DNA is copied and passed from one cell generation to the next generation.DNA is organized into chromosomes and found within the nucleus of our cells. Its function in any cell is to carry the sequence of bases which will be transcribed into RNA. RNA then has many function within the cellThese molecules are responsible for passing on genetic informationThese molecules are used to create another important molecule known as RNAThese molecules are organized into chromosonesCellular respirationCellular respiration is what cells do to break up sugars into a form that the cell can use as energy. Cellular respiration takes in food and uses it to create ATP, a chemical which the cell uses for energy. Usually, this process uses oxygen, and is called aerobic respiration.It also produces carbon dioxide as a waste product, which then enters the circulatory system. The carbon dioxide is taken to the lungs, where it is exchanged for oxygen. When they don't get enough oxygen, the cells use anaerobic respiration, which doesn’t require oxygen. However, this process produces lactic acid, and is not as efficient as when oxygen is used. The equation for this process is Glucose (sugar) + Oxygen → Carbon dioxide + Water + Energy (as ATP)Every cell does this to produce energy
Heart The Heart's function is to pump blood throughout the body The Heart is considered a muscle The heart consists of four different chambers: the left atrium, the right atrium, the left ventricle and the right ventricle. This organ is made up of four different chambers
Brain The Brain allows us to think, store memories, analyze and make judgments while at the same time controlling other areas automatically, such as breathing. The human brain weighs 3 pounds and is made up of 60% fat. The brain consists of the cerebrum, the brainstem, and the cerebellum. The cerebrum: this is responsible for a number of things like speech, motion, it also controls movement and learning it’s the largest part of the brain. The cerebellum: its main function is for helping with muscle movements, posture and balance\ The brainstem: plays a really important function by connecting the cerebrum and cerebellum to your spinal cord. It automatically looks after many of our bodies function like body temperature, digestion, heart rate and even things like sneezing and coughing.This organ controls all of our bodys vital functions
Lungs Blood runs through our body, goes to the lungs to pick up oxygen from the air we breathe in and then drops off carbon dioxide, which we breathe out. The average adult individual breathes almost 11,000 liters of air every single day. The lungs have special little hairs in tubes in your lungs that move up and out. This helps the special cells that produce mucus. Mucus in the lungs is also specialized as it catches bacteria, dirt and dust that you breathe in as well as bacteria in the air. This organ supplies blood with oxygen, and removes carbon dioxide
Liver The liver is involved in almost every vital function of the body, such as making and storing energy; producing proteins vital for body function; processing drugs, and playing a vital role in immune function. Your liver is the second largest organ (after the skin), it weights about 3 pounds It's the only organ that can completly regenerate, it only needs 25% of the orignial tissue, and can regrow in less than two weeks It is the second largest organ in the body
Kidney Kidneys are two bean shaped organs, that are responsible for creating urine Kidneys make hormones. The two most important ones that it makes are erythropoetin and renin. The kidney's most important work is keeping homeostasis. Homeostasis means that the body keeps a stable environment inside itself This organ is important in keeping homeostasis
